section.para: The module enables you, on behalf of your company (the exporter), to receive Purchase Orders sent by your buyer (the importer). The purchase advice list shows you a list of items that still need to be ordered for items you have selected.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: In this chapter, we use the terms importer and buyer interchangeably, and terms exporter and seller interchangeably.

section.title: Navigation
section.para: To navigate to the Banker's Guarantee function, from the toolbar, select Trade Services > Purchase Order Advice.

section.title: POs and Open Accounts
section.para: An Open Account transaction is one where the goods are shipped and delivered before payment is due. Thus the seller is extending credit to the buyer. This is becoming increasingly common in international trade, compared to more traditional methods such as Letters of Credit.
In , an Open Account is a group of POs that have been stored together ready to be sent in a batch to an exporter.

Your buyer can use to create Open Accounts and send them to your company. You use this module to receive and acknowledge the POs. You use the module, described in chapter Invoice Module, to send the invoices.

section.title: Bank Involvement
section.para: The bank associated with these transactions is known as the Issuing Bank, just as in other modules, even though in this case it does not really issue anything. In this module the bank is more of an observer, since no bank approval is needed for POs and invoices to pass between buyer and seller.

If both the buyer and the seller are users of , the POs and invoices pass directly between them, and are sent to the Issuing Bank for information only, enabling the bank to offer services such as financing.

If only one of the companies is a user of , then communications between them are sent via the Issuing Bank. While one company uses to communicate with the bank, the other must use some other channel such as SWIFT TSU.

section.title: Counterparty Access
section.para: If your company (the seller) is not an existing user of , your buyer can arrange for you to have limited access to to use the and modules.
When your buyer arranges for you to have access to , they should let you know the credentials (user ID, password, and abbreviated name for your company) you can use to log on.

section.title: Purchase Order Notification - Retrieve Unsigned
section.para: This option allows acceptance and resubmission records that you or another user have already started but been unable to submit, to be submitted by an authorised user. When selected, this option will present a list of acceptance and resubmission records that have been prepared and saved by users in your bank, but have not been successfully submitted to the clients because the user had insufficient privileges. Records that were simply saved with no attempt to submit them are not included. Click in the System ID column to open the record in a non-editable mode, in order to review the data and perform the submission.

If you have sufficient authorisation in your profile, you can submit multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page submits all the selected records. The result of the action is then returned, with a list of records that have now been successfully sent to the clients, together with a list of records that have again failed validation. section.para: On the History page, you can click in the Release Date column to open a popup window showing full details of each event. Within the popup, the Event Details section shows the key details of the event. It shows any additional instructions and attachment provided by the customer as well as the bank's comment and attachments given as part of the reporting.

If the Event Details header in the popup window shows a Release Date/Time, it means the time the validated transaction event was released by the buyer to the seller.
The timestamp is shown in user timezone by default. However, it can be changed by setting the property display.datetime.in.user.timezone to 'False' which shows the bank timezone. Banks which want to retain the earlier configuration need to set the listed property to 'False' as well.

The Date/Time field that accompanies a Message header means the time the reporting message was released by the seller to the buyer.
The timestamp is shown in user timezone by default. However, it can be changed by setting the property display.datetime.in.user.timezone to 'False' which shows the bank timezone. Banks which want to retain the earlier configuration need to set the listed property to 'False' as well.

. The name of the file downloaded is the System ID of the transaction together with a .csv extension - for example, if the SO has the system identifier SO0110001008., the filename is SO0110001008.csv (where the first "O" is the letter O, not zero).
